<title
    level="1"
    right="Armor 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Armored Coat](/Armor.aspx?ID=16)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=159" />
<trait label="Comfort" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=203" />
<trait label="Flexible" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=204" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Knights of Lastwall](/Sources.aspx?ID=123) pg. 87</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 20 gp

**AC Bonus** +2

**Dex Cap** +2

**Check Penalty** -1

**Speed Penalty** —
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Strength** 14

**Bulk** 2

**Category** Light

**Group** Leather
</row>

</column>

---

A custom, lightweight mail is fitted within the lining of a coat or similar apparel, physically hiding the armor while maintaining the wearer's fashion. While not nearly as protective as heavier armors, the armored coat allows the wearer to blend in more aesthetically during civilian functions. Like other suits of armor, the armored coat is custom-fitted to an individual's body type, ensuring comfort without sacrificing its defensive capabilities.

<title level="2">Armor Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 275 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain class features can grant you additional benefits with certain armors. This is called an armor specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which armor group your armor belongs to, as listed below. Only medium and heavy armors have armor specialization effects.

[Click here for the full rules on Armor Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=211).

<document level="2" id="armor-group-3" />
